awd_titl_txt: MAPS: The MMT Adaptive optics exoPlanet characterization System
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this program is to develop an adaptive optics (AO) system for the MMT Observatory on Mt. Hopkins Arizona for the observation and characterization of planets orbiting stars other than the sun (exoplanets). The system is abbreviated as MAPS.  Broader impacts of the work include training of students and postdocs in astronomical instrumentation.  The MAPS team will develop an annual winter school focused on training and academic development for undergraduate and graduate students, complemented by advanced high school students identified through UA's existing Astronomy Camp. The week-long school will directly engage MAPS investigators, local astronomy facilities, and authentic data sets relevant to exoplanet characterization.

This award will support technology development for an upgraded adaptive secondary telescope mirror to improve the adaptive optics performance while preserving the desired low backgrounds for long wavelength (infrared) observations.  The ultimate goal of MAPS is to develop the capabilities for (1) high spatial resolution to resolve the planets and disks; (2) high spectral resolution to begin understanding the components of other systems; and (3) broad wavelength coverage to probe systems at the range of wavelengths crucial for thorough study.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The majority of the project work has focused on the instrument design and development of critical hardware components, specifically the actuators that will enable the telescope secondary to change shape to correct for atmospheric effects. The ability of the lower power actuators to respond rapidly and to exhibit a large range of motion was confirmed, and these capabilities are essential not only for the MAPS instrument, but also future telescope projects. For the science component of the project, a series of pilot studies to characterize exoplanet atmospheres with high resolution spectroscopy were developed and approved for current instruments, and initial observations have been taken for these projects. The pilot studies will help with the design of the larger and more sensitive MAPS exoplanet survey. The project broader impacts have involved the training and education of students in this forefront research area of exoplanet atmospheric characterization through advanced observational and theoretical techniques. Students at both undergraduate and graduate levels have learned about the subject of the project from presentations of the MAPS design, review of scientific articles, and preparation of telescope proposals for initial studies with current systems. Students worked on theoretical simulations and also planned and participated in the observations.
